title: BUG: fix parsing by filtering out junk lines
body:
This closes https://github.com/astropy/astroquery/issues/2717

I'm on the fence whether this needs a changelog or not, I suppose it does as lines from the docs stopped working due to these junk lines, e.g. this one 
```
>>> response['FREQ'].quantity
```

title: BUG: JPLSpec: parsing looks off
body:
Example from the docs used to work, but now there are two extra lines that changes the column type to be string.

```
>>> from astroquery.jplspec import JPLSpec
>>> from astropy import units as u
>>> response = JPLSpec.query_lines(min_frequency=100 * u.GHz,
...                                max_frequency=1000 * u.GHz,
...                                min_strength=-500,
...                                molecule="28001 CO")
>>> response['FREQ'].quantity
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
Cell In [18], line 1
----> 1 response['FREQ'][3:].quantity

File ~/munka/devel/astropy/astropy/table/column.py:1085, in BaseColumn.quantity(self)
   1078 """
   1079 A view of this table column as a `~astropy.units.Quantity` object with
   1080 units given by the Column's `unit` parameter.
   1081 """
   1082 # the Quantity initializer is used here because it correctly fails
   1083 # if the column's values are non-numeric (like strings), while .view
   1084 # will happily return a quantity with gibberish for numerical values
-> 1085 return Quantity(
   1086     self, self.unit, copy=False, dtype=self.dtype, order="A", subok=True
   1087 )

File ~/munka/devel/astropy/astropy/units/quantity.py:563, in Quantity.__new__(cls, value, unit, dtype, copy, order, subok, ndmin)
    559 # check that array contains numbers or long int objects
    560 if value.dtype.kind in "OSU" and not (
    561     value.dtype.kind == "O" and isinstance(value.item(0), numbers.Number)
    562 ):
--> 563     raise TypeError("The value must be a valid Python or Numpy numeric type.")
    565 # by default, cast any integer, boolean, etc., to float
    566 if float_default and value.dtype.kind in "iuO":

TypeError: The value must be a valid Python or Numpy numeric type.
```

Previously `response` looked like this:

```
       FREQ     ERR    LGINT   DR   ELO   GUP  TAG   QNFMT QN' QN"
       MHz      MHz   MHz nm2      1 / cm
   ----------- ------ ------- --- ------- --- ------ ----- --- ---
   115271.2018 0.0005 -5.0105   2     0.0   3 -28001   101   1   0
      230538.0 0.0005 -4.1197   2   3.845   5 -28001   101   2   1
...
```

Now it has the two extra lines:

```
        FREQ      ERR    LGINT   DR   ELO    GUP  TAG   QNFMT QN' QN"
       MHz       MHz   nm2 MHz      1 / cm
   ------------- ------ ------- --- -------- --- ------ ----- --- ---
   CADDIR CATDIR     --      --  --       --  --     --    --  --  --
   CADDIR CATDIR     --      --  --       --  --     --    --  --  --
     115271.2018 0.0005 -5.0105   2      0.0   3 -28001   101   1   0
     230538.0000 0.0005 -4.1197   2    3.845   5 -28001   101   2   1
...
```

title: Fix and refactor `esa.hsa` remote tests
body:
Currently many `esa.hsa` remote tests are meant to compare two sorted lists, but the lists are sorted with [`list.sort()`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#list.sort) in the assert statement: https://github.com/astropy/astroquery/blob/a4716fd1db5d0b7162e9d4e879135c36b451dcdf/astroquery/esa/hsa/tests/test_hsa_remote.py#L46
`list.sort()` sorts the list in place, meaning its return value is `None`:
```python
>>> print([1, 2, 3].sort())
None
```
The tests are therefore asserting that `None == None` regardless of the content of the lists. When fixing the tests it became apparent that the checksums are not reproducible, so I changed the tests to verify the filename endings in the tar-files instead.

I also decided to refactor the remote test file. See the commit messages for details.

title: SDSS: Field info are not available for this data release (17)
body:
This query works before (it is part of our remote data test suite downstream) but has stopped working.

```python
from astropy import units as u
from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord
from astroquery.sdss import SDSS

skycoord_center = SkyCoord(6.62754354, 1.54466139, unit="deg")
zoom_radius = 3 * u.arcmin  # Same error even when you make it smaller like 2 arcmin
query_region_result = SDSS.query_region(skycoord_center, radius=zoom_radius, data_release=17)
```
```
WARNING: Field info are not available for this data release [astroquery.sdss.field_names]
WARNING: Field info are not available for this data release [astroquery.sdss.field_names]

<then it tries to parse something incompatible because query failed>

InconsistentTableError: Number of header columns (1) inconsistent with data columns in data line 2
```

I get proper result if I change the data release number:

```python
query_region_result = SDSS.query_region(skycoord_center, radius=zoom_radius, data_release=16)
```

However, 17 is the default data release number:

https://github.com/astropy/astroquery/blob/e388ceb3a17ee75cfed8b773a21a218f7ff0fe3e/astroquery/sdss/__init__.py#L22

title: Catalogs.query_object returns data for the wrong star
body:
```
>>> from astroquery.mast import Catalogs
>>> Catalogs.query_object('WASP-3', radius=0.001, catalog='TIC')
<Table masked=True length=1>
    ID           ra             dec        ... wdflag      dstArcSec
   str9       float64         float64      ... int64        float64
--------- --------------- ---------------- ... ------ -------------------
715677988 83.162492515507 7.54537790157609 ...      0 0.02982868249131487
```

This is the wrong star, WASP-3 is TIC 27848472 according to SIMBAD and the MAST portal.
The actual coordinates of WASP-3 are 278.631773297363, 35.6615247759849.
The correct star is returned if I use an alternative identifier for this star ('BD+35 3293')

title: Allow remote tests that follow cache tests to succeed
body:
Previously the cache tests permanently replaced `requests.Session.request`, which caused the following remote tests to fail. Now the replacement is handled by a test fixture, which ensures it does not affect any tests that do not want to be affected. Furthermore, the fixture can automatically change the mocked response after being queried once, which reduces manual setup needed in the cache tests.

Fixes #2632

title: BUG: cache test mockreturn gets outside the test scope
body:
We see a lot of recentish remote test failures that ca be sourced back to the addition of the new cache tests, a bug in mocking the response in them.

Smallest way to reproduce, e.g.:

```
pytest astroquery/tests/ astroquery/vsa -R
```

then remove `astroquery/tests/test_cache.py`, and it all passes


cc @ceb8

title: Add blank table handling for new returns from heasarc
body:
HEASARC is returning FITS files with blank data and a little header metadata as null results now, so we need to handle them.

WIP: requires a test.

title: CI: test all dependencies in the oldestdeps job
body: We should be able to catch issues with our dependencies, and if we declare minimum version, we should in fact test with those in CI

title: BUG: fix skyview radius
body:
Easy fix, but no one picked it up in the past year. The PR also works towards #1746
This should close #2190

title: BUG: nasa_exoplanet_archive get_query_payload to return actual query
body:
This is to close https://github.com/astropy/astroquery/issues/2129

The logic is very similar to #2585 (and also detailed in the issue). With this PR all modules that have get_query_payload kwarg seem to return the SQL query when available, or the payload dict if it's passed directly into a GET/POST request.

title: ENH: get_query_payload to return useful info
body: The naming of the kwarg is somewhat misleading, we should aim it to return the payload that is in fact sent out to the server, not an intermediate one in our library yet to be processed further. So in this case the adql query string is more useful than a payload dictionary yet to be process to generate the query string.

title: DOC: alma.get_data_info() function does not take 'obs_id' argument
body:
Hi all,

The example from [https://astroquery.readthedocs.io/en/latest/alma/alma.html#downloading-fits-data](https://astroquery.readthedocs.io/en/latest/alma/alma.html#downloading-fits-data) does not work. The **alma.get_data_info** function takes as argument strings in the **'member_ous_uid'** column in the results table, the example on the provided link shows the function taking as argument strings from the **'obs_id'** column in the results table. If using the example provided at the link, the following error is returned:

`WARNING: Error accessing info about file : NotFoundFault: uid://A001/X8a9/X2c.source.S255_NIRS3.spw.25 [astroquery.alma.core]`

This was done using astroquery version 0.4.7.dev8076
All the best,
Toma

title: Remove default wavelength limits from `svo_fps` `get_filter_index()`
body:
So far the default behaviour of `get_filter_index()` from `svo_fps` has been to make the wavelength range as large as possible, but that results in a timeout. Now the method requires the user to explicitly set the wavelength limits. Although this is backwards incompatible, in practice the user already had to provide the limits and if they don't then it is better to receive an immediate `TypeError` about missing mandatory arguments than it is to wait a minute before an obscure timeout occurs.

See also 90677c86b69e7ea33a131d7a7cfc8282cd157f6b

Closes #2508

title: Cannot connect to SVO Filter Profile Service
body:
There seem to be connectivity issues with the SVO Filter Profile Service (FPS). The following code (from the [tutorial](https://astroquery.readthedocs.io/en/latest/svo_fps/svo_fps.html))

```
from astroquery.svo_fps import SvoFps
index = SvoFps.get_filter_index()
```

gives the following error:

```
ReadTimeout: HTTPConnectionPool(host='svo2.cab.inta-csic.es', port=80): Read timed out. (read timeout=60)
```

Since I can access the SVO FPS directly via my web browser, I assume the problem must lie somewhere in the interface between Astroquery and the SVO FPS.

title: converting input lists to np arrays
body: `astroquery.mast.Observations.get_product_list` was mishandling lists because the assumed input was a numPy array. This led to incorrect requests being made to our API. This PR adds a conditional to catch for incoming lists to convert them into numPy arrays before handling. Before: -- After: --

title: JWST MAST product lists often list and download the same product multiple times
body:
The `astroquery.mast` interface for getting JWST data products from single or multiple observations seems to get the same product many times and then downloads the same product over and over again, sometimes hundreds of times, depending on the product and dataset.

There needs to be a unique culling before downloads start in order to avoid this.  In fact, this is what the MAST web site does - culls before creating the download tarball or download curl script.  But `astroquery.mast` does not do this.

Here's a small example of the problem, using NIRSpec MSA observations for the SMACS cluster EROs.  I just want to get the MSA configuration files used for the observations.  A priori, I don't know how many there are.

```python

import numpy as np


obs_table = Observations.query_criteria(proposal_id="2736", instrument_name="NIRSPEC")

              parent_obsid  str8     0
                dataRights  str6     0
               calib_level int64     0
```
So 964 rows for this observation.  Which is the MSA config file?  I want to find the rows where `dataURI` has _msa.fits.  One can use `np.char.find` which can look in an array and return an array of the location of a substring in each element, or -1 if it doesn't find it.  We need a boolean mask to select the rows of the table that have the MSA files.  So:

```python
mask = np.char.find(data_products["dataURI"], "_msa.fits") != -1
data_products = data_products[mask]
data_products["dataURI"]
<MaskedColumn name='dataURI' dtype='str70' length=6>
mast:JWST/product/jw02736008001_01_msa.fits
mast:JWST/product/jw02736008001_01_msa.fits
mast:JWST/product/jw02736008001_01_msa.fits
mast:JWST/product/jw02736008001_01_msa.fits
mast:JWST/product/jw02736008001_01_msa.fits
mast:JWST/product/jw02736008001_01_msa.fits
```

So there's only 1 MSA config file for this observation (makes sense), but it is listed 6 times.

And if I download these

```python
manifest = Observations.download_products(data_products)
```

It will download the MSA config file 6 times.  If I blindly download all the NIRSpec data for this proposal, all 244 observations, it will download that MSA config file almost 700 times.  It only checks if the files are on disk once before starting downloads.  It will happily keep downloading the same file if it is listed ~700 times in the `data_products` table.

The MSA config file above is just an example.  But this is problem for lots of JWST data, including SCIENCE data.  If I look at 10 observations (so as not to trigger the 600s timeout):

```python
from astropy.table import unique


data_products = Observations.get_product_list(obs_table[100:110])
len(data_products)
10308

data_products = Observations.filter_products(data_products, productType="SCIENCE")
len(data_products)
718

data_products_unique = unique(data_products, keys="dataURI")
len(data_products_unique)
246
```

It looks like on average, each product will be downloaded 3 times.  So all the science data is also being listed multiple times, given how MAST has organized their tables.  One can see this pretty clearly in the web interface as well showing the MSA files below.

![Screen Shot 2022-08-19 at 10 39 28](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17088869/185580066-643b1d1c-a5f2-4f43-a5ea-3b25bdc910b4.png)

Anyway, I think a `unique(data_products, keys="dataURI")` or similar needs to be done internally before downloads start, probably somewhere in `Observations.download_products()`.  Currently, anyone using the `astroquery.mast` interface is downloading most of their data multiple times and putting big strain on the MAST server.  And it takes forever.

title: Astrometry.net: Improvements to API key warnings/errors
body: Possible fix for https://github.com/astropy/astroquery/issues/2482 - only raise an error about missing API key when it is needed, otherwise user doesn't have chance to set it before the warning is emitted.

title: BUG: raise for unsupported arguments for alma
body: Throw `TypeError` for unused arguments when generating query.

title: Throw an error when unsupported arguments are passed in `astroquery.alma`
body:
A user recently tried to issue this:

```python
from astroquery.alma import Alma
from astropy import units as u
rs = Alma.query_object("V* CW Cha", radius=0.05*u.arcmin, public=True, science=True)
print(len(set(rs['obs_id'])))
```

The `query_object` function does *not* support the `radius` argument.  The function they actually want is `query_region`, but calling `query_object` still succeeds quietly but is misleading to the caller.  Functions should error out when unsupported arguments are passed to the query functions.

the `cds` module needs some updates to refactor the current usage of deprecated mocpy functionality (this will be responsible for most of the remote-data test failures coming from this module)

title: BUG: alma fixes for list of keywords, fixes #2094
body:
ADQL not handling lists of strings properly.  Existing `OR` logic was used instead of introducing `IN` clause.


fixes #2094

title: SvoFps.get_filter_index unit conversion issue?
body:
```
wmin = 5000 * units.angstrom
wmax = 7000 * units.angstrom
index_a = svo.get_filter_index(wavelength_eff_min = wmin, \
                                                 wavelength_eff_max = wmax, timeout = 180)
```

returns 3026 filters, but changing the units to micron, as follows:

```
wmin = 0.5 * units.micron
wmax = 0.7 * units.micron
index_m = svo.get_filter_index(wavelength_eff_min = wmin, \
                                                 wavelength_eff_max = wmax, timeout = 180)
```

throws an IndexError:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.9/site-packages/astroquery/svo_fps/core.py", line 58, in data_from_svo
    return parse_single_table(votable).to_table()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.9/site-packages/astropy/io/votable/table.py", line 180, in parse_single_table
    return votable.get_first_table()

  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.9/site-packages/astropy/io/votable/tree.py", line 3719, in get_first_table
    raise IndexError("No table found in VOTABLE file.")
IndexError: No table found in VOTABLE file.

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.9/site-packages/astroquery/svo_fps/core.py", line 87, in get_filter_index
    return self.data_from_svo(query=query, error_msg=error_msg, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.9/site-packages/astroquery/svo_fps/core.py", line 61, in data_from_svo
    raise IndexError(error_msg)
IndexError: No filter found for requested Wavelength Effective range

```
`get_filter_index` should be able to internally convert the units to Angstrom if that's what causing this issue.

title: MAINT: remove xfail from passing test
body:
Currently, 4 remote alma tests are failing, one of them because it is passing as opposed to its xfail mark.

The other three are a different case, locally and on CI I see certificate issues like the one below. One puzzling question is why the tests use the noa.ac.jp mirror, as I recall we kind of hard wired the ESO server not long ago.

Maybe @keflavich or @andamian could have a look? (I suppose the first failure just requires to rework the test, or maybe even removing it as its name suggests that it served as testing the documentation (test_doc_example), however now we have doctest running on the narrative docs.

```

title: BUG: Fix OAC parsing issue
body:
This is to fix #1401 as well as to fix the now passing, previously xfailing tests.


First I was thinking of removing the `data_format` kwarg as it shouldn't be the concern of the users of which data format to receive the query response, but parsing the json into an astropy table is not trivial without pulling in pandas as a dependency. So I opted for a regex fix instead.

title: BUG: fix expected dictionary responses
body:
The async queries return a repose, use the sync versions instead for table return. And fix the dictionary snippets as responses, those are not at all like the results we got from the queries. Use ELLIPSIS, etc instead but show something realistic in the docs.

cc @mkelley

title: BUG: pre-release is not picked up for the predeps tox env
body: This can be easily experimented on while astropy is in RC

title: MNT: Fix incomplete URLs in regrex
body: These were picked up by codeQL as potential risks.

title: Fix molecule parsing issue for CDMS
body:
WIP: this fixes only half the problem.  Tests are needed.

Problem is described in #2375: there are molecules with `()`'s in the names that break the regex.  The current fix escapes those automatically.  

There's a second problem: the fixed-width parser fails for some subset of molecules.  Todo:

- [x] figure out what the correct parsing is for H2C(CN)2 (it is not obvious!)
- [x] find a generalized way to parse different molecular files (there does not appear to be a header for any of them?)

title: Bugfix: SBDB query return unit with exponentials
body: When SBDB query returns quantities that have units with exponentials, an error is issued because '^' is used to mark exponentials instead of '**' in the unit strings.  Issue #2368 .  This PR fixes this bug.

title: JPL SBDB query fails when returned properties have complex units with exponential involved
body:
For the objects that have properties that involve complex units, such as asteroid Bennu which has density and thermal inertia etc. to be returned, `SBDB` reports an error because the exponential in the units uses '^' rather than '**'.

```
from astroquery.jplsbdb import SBDB
sbdb = SBDB.query('bennu', phys=True)
```

Also it looks like `astropy.units.Unit` doesn't recognize decimal points when it's in the exponential.  The decimal point has to be put inside a pair of parentheses.  While this is an `astropy` issue, it affects how `SBDB` would parse units.

```
import astropy.units as u
print(u.Unit('m**(0.5)'))
print(u.Unit('m**0.5'))
```

astroquery==0.4.7.dev7713

title: Failing ESA remote tests
body:
Some tests are failing due to relatively recent changes to the default file saving mechanism in tapplus. Some of this were discussed already in the relevant PR, but I'm opening this issue so the problem is not hidden in a  merged PR: https://github.com/astropy/astroquery/pull/2311#issuecomment-1081441659

I don't think the PR introduced any issues for the users, nevertheless, the tests should be fixed. To reproduce the failures:

``python setup.py test -P esa,esasky,gaia,utils.tap -R``


cc @jespinosaar 

related issues for tracking remote failures: #2203

/private/var/folders/dc/hsm7tqpx2d57n7vb3k1l81xw0000gq/T/astroquery-test-r53oieer/lib/python3.9/site-packages/docs/atomic/atomic.rst:32: UnexpectedException
================================================================= short test summary info ==================================================================
FAILED docs/atomic/atomic.rst::atomic.rst
=============================================================== 1 failed, 9 passed in 3.35s ================================================================
```

All the while if I add the `cache=False` kwarg the doctesting passes as expected, too.

I haven't seen this type of issues with any of the other modules, so it may not be a generic caching issue, but something specific to atomic.

title: Full gaia failure
body:
Something goes very wrong, it seems that the response is not what is expected. Example is the first one from the docs, but all remote tests are failing as well:

```
from astroquery.gaia import Gaia
from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord
import astropy.units as u
coord = SkyCoord(ra=280, dec=-60, unit=(u.degree, u.degree), frame='icrs')
width = u.Quantity(0.1, u.deg)
height = u.Quantity(0.1, u.deg)
r = Gaia.query_object(coordinate=coord, width=width, height=height)
```

Even though this is not due to some recent changes,  I treat this as a release blocker and hope that a quick fix will be possible, either server-side or in astroquery which would end up in this release.


cc @mhsarmiento @jcsegovia

title: CADC int tests failing
body:
3 cadc int tests are failing.

2 of them (`test_get_images`, `test_get_images_async`) fail with a `VOTable` parse error which can be caused either by service or VOTable incompatibilities with the spec. It requires further investigation.
```
warning = E02('?:?:?: E02: Incorrect number of elements in array. Expected multiple of 2, got 1')
config = {'_warning_counts': {<class 'astropy.io.votable.exceptions.E02'>: 1}}
stacklevel = 3

    def _suppressed_warning(warning, config, stacklevel=2):
        warning_class = type(warning)
        config.setdefault('_warning_counts', dict()).setdefault(warning_class, 0)
        config['_warning_counts'][warning_class] += 1
        message_count = config['_warning_counts'][warning_class]
        if message_count <= conf.max_warnings:
            if message_count == conf.max_warnings:
                warning.formatted_message += \
                    ' (suppressing further warnings of this type...)'
>           warn(warning, stacklevel=stacklevel+1)
E           astropy.io.votable.exceptions.E02: ?:?:?: E02: Incorrect number of elements in array. Expected multiple of 2, got 1
```

The third one (test_list_jobs) is failing in `PyVO` with an unexpected element. Again incompatibilities with the spec in either the service or `PyVO` - to be investigated.

```
>           warn(warning, stacklevel=stacklevel+1)
E           pyvo.utils.xml.exceptions.UnknownElementWarning: None:2:0: UnknownElementWarning: Unknown element jobs
``

title: Possible fix for issue2294: don't pickle hooks
Problem with MPC.get_observations
body:
I am getting "Ran out of input" or "_pickle.PicklingError: Can't pickle <class 'astropy.utils.masked.core.MaskedQuantity'>: attribute lookup MaskedQuantity on astropy.utils.masked.core failed" on certain objects. Querying on the MPC website successfully return observations of these objects, and there is no obvious pattern to me on the objects that fail.

For example, when trying to run the example [here](https://astroquery.readthedocs.io/en/latest/mpc/mpc.html#observations):

```
>>> from astroquery.mpc import MPC
>>> MPC.get_observations(12893)
```

I am getting "Ran out of input" error on astroquery=0.4.5, but it runs without issue on 0.4.1. However, if I try `MPC.get_observations(12894)`, I am getting the PicklingError on both versions. I see that #2280 refers to the same PicklingError during initialization, not sure if it is relevant.

Any thoughts/pointers are appreciated. Thanks!

title: Fixed failing test in HEASARC module, adding local test data
body:
The test fails with astropy==5.0. Which indicates correctly that most of the module functionality breaks. 
There is some complexity in astropy with version check in 5.0, but I noticed everything works fine with the latest astropy `main` branch.
Meanwhile, and nevertheless, might be good to just always specify the unit, this will work with all relevant astropy versions.

I also update test according to some server-side change. 

I wonder how to prevent this sort of problem from emerging at some point.
 It would be good to have non-remote tests I guess. Only non-remotes ones are likely to continue passing?

I could just copy the entire  `astroquery/heasarc/tests/test_heasarc_remote_isdc.py` to  `astroquery/heasarc/tests/test_heasarc_remote_isdc.py` and add monkeypatches according to the [doc](https://astroquery.readthedocs.io/en/latest/testing.html#monkeypatching), is this the recommended way?

title: Nasa Exoplanet Archive `query_object` method suddenly produces InvalidTableError
body:
I have previously many times used the following snippet of code to query for exoplanetary properties from the NASA Exoplanet Archive:
```
from astroquery.nasa_exoplanet_archive import NasaExoplanetArchive 
planet_properties = NasaExoplanetArchive.query_object(planet_name) # planet_name is a string, ie. 'kepler-69b'.

```
However, this recently started producing the following error:
`InvalidTableError: 'aliastable' is not a valid table`

I have tried updating the import statement to 
`from astroquery.ipac.nexsci.nasa_exoplanet_archive import NasaExoplanetArchive`
as I believe this was recently updated, but that does not solve the issue.

I apologize if the issue is on my end, but I would very much appreciate any information about what might be causing this (and how to solve). Thanks in advance.

title: Cache issues with JPLhorizons
body:
Hi, 

I encountered this issue with JPLHorizons, but it might be present for other services. 

For a brief moment, the Horizons API was returning errors to my queries. 
Those queries have been stored in the cache although astroquery was recognizing them as faulty queries. 
It resulted that when the issue was fixed on the Horizons side, my astroquery queries were still returning the same error as it was using the cache and was not trying to query Horizons again. 

I thus had to add a try and catch to all my programs to avoid this issue and using a cache=False when the regular call with the cache fails while this could be built in the JPLHorizons module to not store the cache when the query fails

For the example, here was the error that the JPLHorizons was returning to me was: 

ValueError: Query failed without known error message; received the following response:
BATVAR: no TLIST values found (or missing quotes)
WLDINI: error loading execution-control file.

Thanks!

title: Docs build shouldn't allow warnings
body: We should enable `-W` on RTD, as otherwise we just rot the docs without noticing. Currently there are various warnings, and thus I open this issue as a reminder that it has to be fixed.

title: Gallery examle no10 downloads large amount of data
body:
The "Retrieve Hubble archival data of M83 and make a figure" example (https://astroquery.readthedocs.io/en/latest/gallery.html#example-10) downloads an awful lot of data (I've stopped the run at 6+GB, it wasn't clear how much longer would it go), which is totally unnecessary for showcasing an astroquery functionality. It would be great to rephrase or even totally exchange that example to involve only a small amount of data.

This is related to #863, #1905 and even may be even #307 (the latter only if we decide to go with a sphinx gallery approach for the examples)

cc @jaymedina @tomdonaldson

title: Querying too many objects runs into maxQueryStringLength for Sdss.query_region -- fix vectorization of queries
body:
I am trying to extract spectra from SDSS with astroquery. Before I get to this step I encounter a problem - the following throws an error:

```
from astroquery.sdss import SDSS
from astropy import coordinates as coords

query = "select top 100                        z, ra, dec, bestObjID                      from                        specObj                      where                        class = 'galaxy'                        and programname = 'eboss'"
res = SDSS.query_sql(query)
co = coords.SkyCoord(ra=res['ra'], dec=res['dec'], unit='deg')
result = SDSS.query_region(co, spectro=True)
```
The error is:

```
ValueError: Some errors were detected !
    Line #12 (got 3 columns instead of 1)
    Line #32 (got 5 columns instead of 1)
```

Strangely enough, if in the query `top 100` is replaced with `top 10` everything is fine. So there is a problem with only a part of the objects. I thought the problem might be just limited to eBoss entries in the database, so tried substituting `programname = 'eboss'` with `instrument='SDSS'` and the problem appeared even then. Is there a solution or some kind of a workaround to this? Thank you!

title: The radius in SkyView get_image_list is actually diameter
body:
The code (copied below) seems to use `radius` as the size of the field of view to query. 

If my understanding is correct, the code should be updated such that 
(1) the name of it should be `diameter` rather than `radius`, to avoid backward incompatible change
(2) change the code to use `2*radius` for size

The code:
```python
# https://github.com/astropy/astroquery/blob/main/astroquery/skyview/core.py#L253
# original code
        if radius is not None:
            size_deg = str(radius.to(u.deg).value)
        elif width and height:
            size_deg = "{0},{1}".format(width.to(u.deg).value,
                                        height.to(u.deg).value)

# Change to
        # either 
        if diameter is not None:
            size_deg = str(diameter.to(u.deg).value)

        # or
        if radius is not None:
            size_deg = str(2*radius.to(u.deg).value)
```
How do you think?

milestone.title: v0.4.4

body:
In #2139, it was reported that SIMBAD can sometimes return incomplete VOTables that don't parse correctly.

This implements a general solution of not caching those responses.  It doesn't specifically address the problem, but makes the solution (re-run the query) much easier!

I think without understanding precisely where the issue is coming from, and how often it occurs, we should limit our response to this for now.

title: `astroquery.mast Catalogs`: HSC spectra downloaded with incorrect filename
body:
While writing my unit tests for `Catalogs` I found a bug in `Catalogs.download_hsc_spectra` that's due to a small typo on Line 471: https://github.com/astropy/astroquery/blob/7de90842fae95524c67173de4bae3f7d7a705aec/astroquery/mast/collections.py#L471. Basically all the files are downloaded with the name `{spec['DatasetName']}.fits` instead of with the observation's unique dataset name. See below: 

```
In [46]: table[1]['DatasetName']
Out[46]: 'HAG_J072655.69+691648.9_J8HPAOZMQ_V01.SPEC1D'

In [47]: r = Catalogs.download_hsc_spectra(table[1])
Downloading URL https://hla.stsci.edu/cgi-bin/ecfproxy?file_id=spec["DatasetName"].fits to ./mastDownload/HSC/{spec['DatasetName']}.fits ...
|=======================================================================|  37 / 37  (100.00%)         0s

In [48]: ls ./mastDownload/HSC/
{spec['DatasetName']}.fits
```

The fix is quick. Just fixing a string formatting typo on what is currently Line 471. PR will be linked.

title: astroquery.esa.xmm_newton misleading error message when downloading data
body:
Try this:

```
from astroquery.esa.xmm_newton import XMMNewton as xmm
obsid = 'abcd'
xmm.download_data(obsid,level="ODF")
```
The error message says: 
`LoginError: Data protected by proprietary rights. Please check your credentials`

This is incorrect and could lead to confusion, the error should indicate that the `OBS_ID` is not found or is not public (depending on the case).

title: query_region_async in VizieR queries ignores some units
body:
Looking at the code of `query_region_async` for VizieR, I noticed that some variables are not used. These are `o_unit` (the unit of the outer radius for queries including both the inner and the outer radius) and `h_unit` (the unit of the hight of a box for rectangular queries). In practice, the resulting queries are built only considering the unit of the inner radius (for cone queries) or the unit of the width of a box (for box queries). This clearly can lead to wrong requests if the units are different.

A minimal modification in the code should at least include a check that the units are the same; a slightly more advanced change would transform all quantities to a common unit.

title: Pending correction to ALMA TAP metadata for `bandwidth`
body: I noticed that the `bandwidth` column of ALMA archive queries purports to be in GHz but is actually in Hz. I have brought this up with @alipnick and a ticket has been filed to fix this upstream. Per @keflavich's request, I am opening an issue here, so that the documentation can be re-generated (i.e., the `Alma.help_tap()` output) after the metadata is fixed upstream.

title: Sporadic caching of 404s
body:
In my intro to observational astronomy class this week, two students out of 19 encountered an error in which an attempt to retrieve an image from SkyView resulted in a 404 error, then repeat calls also returned the 404 error because it was cached.  I had to manually clear the `~/.astropy/cache/astroquery/SkyView/` folder.

I'm not sure why the `raise_for_status` calls.... ah.  There are no `raise_for_status` calls.  This is a simple bug to fix: don't accept non-successful HTTP requests in SkyView!

(more generally, we should review code and make sure all requests `raise_for_status` by default)

title: Using specobj_fields with query_crossid()
body:
I have a huge list of SDSS objects that I am trying to obtain `photoobj` and `specobj` information for using the `query_crossid()` method. I can obtain the desired `photoobj` data no problem. But when I try to include a list of desired `specobj_fields` I get a `ValueError` (see below for a working example and the full error message). 

**My question is: does this error message simply mean that there is no (complete) `specobj` data available for that object? Or is there something wrong with my code that is causing the error?**

```
import numpy as np
from astropy import units as u
from astropy.coordinates import SkyCoord
from astropy.io import fits
from astropy.table import Table
from astroquery.sdss import SDSS

title: get_query_payload should return the sql/tap query when available
body:
I feel it would be more useful to have the sql/tap query returned with `get_query_payload` kwarg rather than the input dictionary when available. The logic with the kwarg is to provide a convenient way to debug problematic queries and it should return whatever is sent to the server.

E.g. instead of `{'table': 'kelttimeseries', 'format': 'ipac'}` I would like to get `"select * from kelttimeseries where kelt_sourceid='KELT_N02_lc_012738_V01_east' kelt_field N02"` that is more appropriate to plug into the web interface.


I've run into this with the nasa_exoplanet_archive module, but it's possible that other modules do the same, too.

title: DOC: Pin sphinx

milestone.title: v0.4.4
milestone.description: A release will be cut before the end of the month as the milestone contains critical fixes for the new JPL Horizons API, and the old API is expected to be turned off soon.

body: See if `sphinx<4` fixes #2111

title: We should be strict about minimum_python_version
body:
We dropped python3.6 support, yet users could pip install 0.4.3 on python3.6, and unrelatedly run into bugs.

Even though the bug in #2112 is not related to python3.6, users should not be able to install it, and we should not patch workarounds to keep things working for unsupported python version.

title: Consider requiring minimum astropy version 4.1
body:
Today we run into a bug that could be traced back to https://github.com/astropy/astropy/pull/9505

The easiest workaround is to drop support for old astropy.

Less easiest to run tests, remote tests with the old dependency combination and the fix all issues that come up. At least the `nasa_exoplanet_archive` module fails on this, but I would not be surprised if there would be more.

(For a failing example: have astropy <4.1 installed, and then run either `pytest astroquery/nasa_exoplanet_carchive --remote-data`, or the following query:

```
>>> from astroquery.nasa_exoplanet_archive import NasaExoplanetArchive
>>> NasaExoplanetArchive.query_object("K2-18 b", cache=False)
```

title: Code examples disappered from rendered docs
body: This may be related to the new pytest directive (I don't think so) or some version issues at RTD. Either case, the builds should have failed and notified us before users run into this...

body:
When using pytest directly, rather than the astropy test runner, quite a few tests are creating files that are not cleaned up after the run. The repo should be left clean of these once the tests are run. I have these after a full run with `--remote-data`.

```

	int_data/
	moc.fits
	tarfile_lightcurves.tar
	target.xml
	w0ji0v01t_c2f.fits.gz
```


edit: maybe add a command at the end of the remote-data tests that lists everything that got generated during the run? maybe even test that no new files are hanging around?

Without knowing anything about the data model of the downloads my workarounds for the tests looks rather hacky, so I would leave this issue to be addressed by the alma experts @keflavich  and @andamian.

Bottom line: 2 remote tests are failing currently, they need to be fixed!

title: Setting MAIN_GAIA_TABLE in astroquery.gaia.Gaia has no effect
body:
Minimum working example demonstrating that setting `Gaia.MAIN_GAIA_TABLE` does not lead to EDR3 results:
```python
import astropy.coordinates as coord
import astropy.units as u
from astroquery.gaia import Gaia
Gaia.MAIN_GAIA_TABLE = 'gaiaedr3.gaia_source'
result_tbl = Gaia.query_object(coord.SkyCoord(37.65032*u.deg, 
                                              89.26089*u.deg), 
                               radius=4*u.arcsec)
print(result_tbl['designation'])
```
(Outputs a Gaia DR2 designation)

astroquery v0.4.2

title: fix a small bug from #2020
body: @bsipocz this fixes the `UnboundLocalError`.  This was a simple omission in that PR.

title: Fix downloaded amount for progressbar
body:
This should fix the progressbar bug that it reports 100% download an order of magnitude prematurely. Apparently, we had this bug since forever.

This is good reminder to switch to use something more standard, e.g. `tqdm` rather than maintaining our homegrown solution at two places. https://github.com/astropy/astropy/issues/4738

title: MNT: Remove pytest.ini
body: `pytest.ini` is overwriting the `addopts` in `setup.cfg`. I was so confused why the warnings won't go away no matter how much I want to ignore it until I realized that `pytest.ini` exists and is taking precedence over `setup.cfg`. I think the `setup.cfg` setting is more correct, but you can also argue that `pytest` config can all move from `setup.cfg` to `pytest.ini`. I'll leave it to your good judgement.

title: astroquery.alma appears to return an incomplete and duplicated antenna listing
body:
Using the following:
```
from astroquery.alma import Alma
alchemi_data = Alma.query(payload={'project_code':'2017.1.00161.L'},public_data=False)
alchemi_data['antenna_arrays'][1057]
```
...it appears that the antenna_arrays listing contains multiple instances of a given antenna (but on different antenna pads)...
```
Out[6]: 'A001:DA44 A001:DV07 A002:DA46 A002:DA51 A005:DV25 A007:DV05 A008:DA42 A008:DV07 A010:DA50 A010:DV13 A011:DV21 A015:DA64 A016:DA44 A016:DV11 A022:DV23 A023:DA41 A023:DA42 A024:DA49 A025:DA46 A025:DV02 A026:DA57 A027:DV06 A033:DA53 A034:DA50 A034:DA55 A035:DA43 A035:DA47 A036:DA45 A039:DV14 A040:DA51 A040:DA55 A042:DV08 A043:DA60 A044:DV03 A044:DV11 A045:DV01 A047:DV15 A048:DA62 A048:DV02 A049:DA47 A049:DV03 A050:DV13 A058:DA41 A058:DA43 A060:DV17 A062:DV10 A066:DV04 A068:DA65 A069:DV16 A070:DA48 A070:DA62 A072:DV20 A073:DA54 A073:DA59 A074:DV09 A075:DA52 A075:DV18 A076:DA59 A076:DA63 A082:DA52 A082:DA54 A083:DV22 A085:DA48 A085:DA63 A086:DA58 A086:DV...'

Several antennas are repeated in the above listing (i.e. DV07).  Is this listing the combination of all antenna pad:antenna pairs that were observed in all sessions observed for a given scheduling block?

title: Coordinates of identifier divided by two
body:
I've already asked the question on [stackoverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/q/66152929/5472354), but I just realized that it probably makes much more sense to ask here.

I'm trying to use `astroquery` to find objects in my images. For some images it works, for others it doesn't and I don't understand why. E.g. for the commented out `qry` it works, but for the other one, the coordinates seem to have been divived by two. What's going on here?


```
from astroquery.simbad import Simbad


custom_simbad = Simbad()
custom_simbad.remove_votable_fields('coordinates')
custom_simbad.add_votable_fields(
    'ra(d)', 'dec(d)', 'coo_err_maja', 'coo_err_mina', 'coo_err_angle',
    'flux(V)', 'flux_error(V)'
)

qry = "region(rotatedbox, 239.6645 -19.13481, 2.208d 2.208d, 18.77721) & " \
      "Vmag < 11.0 & Vmag > -27.0"

# this one works
# qry = "region(rotatedbox, 61.374 +18.62462, 2.210d 2.210d, 162.20635) & " \
#       "Vmag < 11.0 & Vmag > -27.0"

objects = custom_simbad.query_criteria(qry).as_array()
print(objects[['RA_d', 'DEC_d']])
```

Results:

```
[(117.9486170008536, -9.3056044051835)
 (117.9874858113787, -9.1988994115738) 
 (117.7279, -9.3656)
...
```

~~Btw I also don't understand why there are seemingly sometimes two coordinates for one object. Are they listed twice?~~

**EDIT:** ignore that last bit; that was just me missinterpreting how the results were printed...

title: sdss sql not parsing results correctly for old dr
body:
Hi, I was trying to do this with astroquery:

```
from astroquery.sdss import SDSS

SDSS.query_sql("select p.objid, p.ra, p.dec, p.PetroRad_r, p.PetroRadErr_r, p.r, p.err_r\n"
               "from galaxy p\n"
               "where p.objid=587731186203951236\n", timeout=0.1, data_release=7)
```

The same SQL command does return an object on the SDSS website, but it returns nothing with the astroquery code above.

![图片](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/34429853/103553538-8bd05e80-4ee8-11eb-8f1a-deb803a985b6.png)

Then I tried this:

```
from astroquery.sdss import SDSS

SDSS.query_sql("select top 10 p.objid, p.ra, p.dec, p.PetroRad_r, p.PetroRadErr_r, p.r, p.err_r\n"+
               "from photoobj p\n"+
               "where p.objid>587731186203951235", timeout=1, data_release=7, cache=False)
```

And found the issue is probably because astroquery did not parse the result correctly.

![图片](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/34429853/103553262-2c724e80-4ee8-11eb-9a82-c069d061c4ae.png)

I verified that the code below works for me. So maybe we just need to adjust the value of `skip_header` for different DR (presumably 0 for dr<10, and 1 for dr>=10). Hope this would help!

```
import io
import numpy as np
from astropy.table import Table
from astroquery.sdss import SDSS, SDSSClass

class SDSS2Class(SDSSClass):
    def _parse_result(self, response, verbose=False):
        """
        Parses the result and return either a `~astropy.table.Table` or
        `None` if no matches were found.

        Parameters
        ----------
        response : `requests.Response`
            Result of requests -> np.atleast_1d.

        Returns
        -------
        table : `~astropy.table.Table`

        """

        if 'error_message' in io.BytesIO(response.content):
            raise RemoteServiceError(response.content)
        arr = np.atleast_1d(np.genfromtxt(io.BytesIO(response.content),
                                          names=True, dtype=None,
                                          delimiter=',', skip_header=0,
                                          comments='#'))

        if len(arr) == 0:
            return None
        else:
            return Table(arr)

SDSS2 = SDSS2Class()
SDSS2.query_sql("select top 10 p.objid, p.ra, p.dec, p.PetroRad_r, p.PetroRadErr_r, p.r, p.err_r\n"+
                "from photoobj p\n"+
                "where p.objid=587731186203951236", timeout=1, data_release=6, cache=False)
```

![图片](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/34429853/103553909-17e28600-4ee9-11eb-8405-c9e2be35e535.png)

title: BUG: don't cache errors for SkyView
body:
I am querying SkyView (WISE 3.4, 12, and 22 data) using an on-sky positions. Occasionally and randomly (as far as I can tell), a query will return an HTTPError: 404 (not found). If I try to run the query again on the machine, then it will fail with the same error. If I add another decimal to the precision of the position, then it will succeed. If I run the original query on a different machine, then it will succeed. For example:

```
from astroquery.skyview import SkyView
import astropy.units as u

# this may fail occasionally and randomly
position = '175.543, -62.336'
images = SkyView.get_images(position=position, coordinates='J2000', pixels=1024, width=0.5*u.deg, survey='WISE 3.4')

# this will succeed (N.B. the extra decimal of precision in the position)
position = '175.5432, -62.3365'
images = SkyView.get_images(position=position, coordinates='J2000', pixels=1024, width=0.5*u.deg, survey='WISE 3.4')
```

It's as if the original query fails for some reason and then that failure is cached. Then, when the same query is called again, the cached failure is returned. Adding another decimal place forces a new query.

title: Unescaped URIs when making download requests in astroquery.mast are causing failed downloads
body:
@eteq reports that he is having trouble retrieving some files from this query:

```
from astroquery.mast import Observations
import astropy.units as u
obs_table = Observations.query_region("M32", radius=6*u.arcmin)
acs_table = obs_table[obs_table['instrument_name']=='ACS/WFC']
field2 = acs_table[(acs_table['provenance_name']=='HLA')&
                   (acs_table['target_name']=='MESSIER-032-FIELD2')&
                   (acs_table['filters']!='DETECTION')]
data_products_by_obs = Observations.get_product_list(field2)
dled = Observations.download_products(data_products_by_obs)
```
In the downloaded results there are catalog files that contain the text `dataset parameter is required` instead of the catalog data.

The issue appears to be that some MAST URIs contain query parameters and the URIs are not escaped when passed to `_download_file`. The resulting request to the MAST download service is ambiguous and arguments to the URI get dropped. An example URI is `mast:HLA/url/cgi-bin/getdata.cgi?download=1&filename=hst_13691_11_acs_wfc_f814w_daophot_trm.cat`.

I think this is the offending line. There may be other places in the astroquery.mast code where URIs need to be escaped:
https://github.com/astropy/astroquery/blob/c4dde9d99cf6297af2bfcf0cd7f35d29f114e23e/astroquery/mast/observations.py#L530

Tagging @ceb8 as requested!

title: Changelog should be exposed to the narrative docs
body: similarly to https://docs.astropy.org/en/stable/changelog.html

title: 'public=True' in Alma.query() returns more results
body:
When I ran 'Alma.query()', I found that if I set 'public=True', it returns more results than when I set 'public=False'. Here is an example of my code: 
```
from astropy.coordinates import Angle, SkyCoord
from astroquery.alma import Alma
import numpy as np

target = [SkyCoord(ra=187.27792*u.degree, dec=2.05239*u.degree, frame='icrs'), Angle(20*u.arcsec)]
cstr = target[0].fk5.to_string(style='decimal')
payload = {}
payload['ra_dec'] = '{:}, {:}'.format(cstr, target[1].deg)
test1 = Alma.query(payload, science=False, public=True)
test2 = Alma.query(payload, science=False, public=False)
print(len(np.unique(test1['obs_id'])), len(np.unique(test2['obs_id'])))
```
The 'public=True' returns 621 results while the other one returns 55 results. It doesn't make sense to me since I expect 'public=False' will return all projects whether it is public or not. Could you confirm if this is my problem or it is actually an issue of astroquery?

title: Horizons session management
body:
In sunpy we have a function that runs the following (cutdown example):
```python
from astroquery.jplhorizons import Horizons
query = Horizons(*args,**kwargs)
result = query.vectors()
```
and we see the following warnings in our unit tests:
```
Exception ignored in: <ssl.SSLSocket fd=6, family=AddressFamily.AF_INET, type=SocketKind.SOCK_STREAM, proto=6, laddr=('172.21.156.203', 55482), raddr=('137.78.251.144', 443)>
ResourceWarning: unclosed <ssl.SSLSocket fd=6, family=AddressFamily.AF_INET, type=SocketKind.SOCK_STREAM, proto=6, laddr=('172.21.156.203', 55482), raddr=('137.78.251.144', 443)>
```

Adding `query._session.close()` removes these warnings but it feels like a hack to do it this way. Is there a better way to manage the session and have it autoclose?

title: Fix utils functions in the alma module
body:
`astroquery.alma` has been re-factored to use the new TAP services at ALMA but there was not time or resources available to update the functions in `utils` module so this has become a technical debt.

`test_alma_utils.test_make_finder_chart` should be re-enabled when this is fixed.

title: Ukidss.list_databases() fails
body:
When trying to use the `list_databases` method of `Ukidss` I get the following error.

```
In [1]: from astroquery.ukidss import Ukidss                                    
dbus[49296]: Dynamic session lookup supported but failed: launchd did not provide a socket path, verify that org.freedesktop.dbus-session.plist is loaded!
dbus[49296]: Dynamic session lookup supported but failed: launchd did not provide a socket path, verify that org.freedesktop.dbus-session.plist is loaded!

In [2]: Ukidss.list_databases()                                                 
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-2-5e67702382f5> in <module>
----> 1 Ukidss.list_databases()

/opt/local/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.6/lib/python3.6/site-packages/astroquery/wfau/core.py in list_databases(self)
    674         List the databases available from the WFAU archive.
    675         """
--> 676         self.databases = set(self.all_databases + self._get_databases())
    677         return self.databases
    678 

TypeError: can only concatenate tuple (not "list") to tuple
```

Both the underlying `all_databases` member and `_get_databases` method are working. The problem appears to be that the `_get_databases` member is returning a list. This should be fixable by replacing line 676 of `wfau/core.py` with:
```
        self.databases = set(self.all_databases + tuple(self._get_databases()))
```
or
```
        self.databases = set(list(self.all_databases) + self._get_databases())
```
This is with Python 3.6 and 3.7 using astroquery 0.4 and 0.4.1.

title: cds tests should not fail without mocpy

mocpy is an optional dependency, so the cds tests should not fail when it's not available, but should be skipped.

I open the issue as a reminder, as this is not release critical and I might not get to this today before tagging 0.4.1

title: jplhorizons remote tests fail
body: The remote tests have been failing for a few days. It seems related with the new ObsSub lon and lat headers, and maybe others too, that where introduced for observer tables recently and cannot be found. I've been in contact with JPL people and will try to figure out what happened.

title: keep original extension for data download
body:
Currently download files are encapsulated in a tar. We don't want that,it's strange for the user

We want to keep the original format, that is, the downloaded file has to keep its structure, extension, if we download it from here or if we download it from curl for example. This PR fix this.


**Changes**

- The downloaded data keep the same extension as the original download via curl for example or https.
- A new test has been added to test the download of a single file. `test_download_data_single_file`

title: missing column names for SDSS SQL queries to old DRs
body:
Queries to old SDSS DRs return results where the column names are taken from the first row of data. This happens because the response text in the old DRs does not start with a commented `#Table` line, but rather has the column names on line 1. The first line, however, is skipped by `genfromtxt` in [sdss/core.py:864](https://github.com/astropy/astroquery/blob/cfabf3a3d2de515b851730f26825f961d2bbc2d3/astroquery/sdss/core.py#L862-L865):

```py
        arr = np.atleast_1d(np.genfromtxt(io.BytesIO(response.content),
                                          names=True, dtype=None,
                                          delimiter=',', skip_header=1,
                                          comments='#'))
```

Since comment lines are skipped anyway it might be ok to remove `skip_header=1`?

title: Fix broken master: xmm relative imports
body: I broke master by moving xmm down a level b/c it had non-relative imports.  This fixes those and hopefully will fix travis.

title: Missmatch between Vizier in Astroquery and real Vizier
body:
According to Vizier, the _Cntr_ parameter in the 2MASS Catalog, for the star 2MASS J02592142+0018056, is **1139104663**, as can be seen [here](https://vizier.u-strasbg.fr/viz-bin/VizieR-5?-ref=VIZ5e7247cf1643&-out.add=.&-source=II/246/out&2MASS===02592142%2b0018056&-out.orig=o).

If I want to search this value from python using astroquery I would assume that this code would suffice:

```
from astroquery.vizier import Vizier

id =  'J02592142+0018056'
t = Vizier(columns = ['_MASS', 'Cntr']).query_object(id, catalog = ['II/246/out'])[0]
print(t[t['_2MASS'] == id[1:]]['Cntr'][0])
```
But the result is the number **32767** and not 1139104663 as intended.
Why is so? Am I doing this wrong?

title: MPC format issue with satellites
body:
Hello,

I was re-directed here from the astropy github with an issue I had using an astroquery package:

I was performing a task that required grabbing the MPC observations of several asteroids. I requested that the MPC format was maintained, as this was necessary for me, but there seems to be a bug with the way astropy parses satellite observations within these files. Rather than having one line with the observation and another with the satellite identification, both 80 characters long, astropy instead grabs these as a single 160-character long line, which was causing one of my tools to not read these observations correctly.

The step to reproduce this is quite simple, we just need to use:

obs = MPC.get_observations(Asteroid_number,get_mpcformat=True), and look for any line where the observation is identified with a capital "S".

Please let me know if this is indeed a bug within astropy, or if there is possibly some feature that allows to fix this.

Best regards,
João Ferreira

title: Cache problem
body:
I discovered when using the service astroquery.mast.Tesscut that if I manually delete my cache I can't call Tesscut again until I restart my python kernel.  I haven't tried this with any other astroquery service that uses caching, so I can't be sure, but looking at the code it seems likely to be a problem in astroquery's caching code rather than Tesscut. 

Version: bleeding edge (what was on master as of 3 Feb 2020).

To reproduce:
1) `from astroquery.mast import Tesscut`
2) Navigate to astroquery cache (`/<home or whatever>/.astropy/cache/astroquery`) and delete everything in it
3) `Tesscut.get_sectors(coordinates="324.24368 -27.01029")`

Traceback:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9406508/73755449-0bcbd280-4734-11ea-80d2-25791fb2e40f.png)

title: Fix skybot unumbered asteroid return
body:
the Skybot service (imcce.Skybot) returns unnumered asteroids ID numbers as non numeric values ('-'), failing when casting these to int `[int(float(n)) for n in results['Number']]`.

Fixed by using a masked column.

CADC Bug fix for radius parsing
body: Allow `astropy.units.Quantity` as input for radius. Fix for issue #1440.

title: Parse error VOTable in XMatch
body:
When there is an error in XMatch a VOTable is returned with description of the error. Parse this table and raise a more informative error than `response.reason` that comes out of `response.raise_for_status()` automatically.

xref: https://github.com/astropy/astroquery/issues/1376

title: IRSA_ibe `list_mission` method not working due to an HTML parsing error of some kind.
body:
I'm trying to use the `ibe` module of astroquery. As a first step, I wanted to go through the `list_missions`, `list_datasets`, and `list_tables` methods to get an idea for what has been implemented. When I call the `list_missions` method, though, I get nonsense. 
```
In [1]: from astroquery.ibe import IbeClass 
In [2]: Irsa = IbeClass()
In [3]: Irsa.list_missions()
/opt/local/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.6/lib/python3.6/site-packages/bs4/__init__.py:181: UserWarning: No parser was explicitly specified, so I'm using the best available HTML parser for this system ("lxml"). This usually isn't a problem, but if you run this code on another system, or in a different virtual environment, it may use a different parser and behave differently.

The code that caused this warning is on line 5 of the file /opt/local/bin/ipython-3.6. To get rid of this warning, change code that looks like this:

 BeautifulSoup(YOUR_MARKUP})

to this:

 BeautifulSoup(YOUR_MARKUP, "lxml")

  markup_type=markup_type))

['',

```

I've manually constructed the URL and checked in my browser and using astroquery's `BaseQuery._request` and can confirm that my system is recieving HTML of some kind, but there seems to be something going wrong in these lines of the `list_missions` method:
https://github.com/astropy/astroquery/blob/a1c4276e7045f7a83ed283e39a44405e78188b2b/astroquery/ibe/core.py#L277-L279

System information: Macbook Pro, MacOS X 10.14.4, using python 3.6 installed via MacPorts (version 3.6.8), astropy installed using the MacPorts package `py36-astropy` (version 3.1), astroquery installed using the MacPorts `pip-3.6` (pip version 19.0.3, astroquery version 0.3.9), and the Beautiful Soup is version 4.6.0 (looks like it was installed by pip).  I have no idea what version of lxml I'm using nor what it was installed by.

title: Occasional raw HTML codes in NIST results break FixedWidth Table parsing
body:
Atomic transition searches from NIST occasionally contain footnotes which display information when hovered over. The addition of such symbols to the HTML code returned from a query can break the parsing of the results into a useable Astropy Table object.

Specifically, the results for vanadium I contain a lot of entries where either the upper or lower energy level is marked with a dagger symbol (†), HTML: `†`. (A specific example is the V I line with a vacuum wavelength of 433.3330 nm, but I found 77 instances over the wavelength range from ~430–625 nm.) The addition of the HTML to the returned text breaks the parsing of the results, as shown below:

Here's the row of the table as it's returned from Nist.query:
```
Observed Transition       Ei           Ek                   Lower level                         Upper level           
-------- ---------- --------------------------- ------------------------------------ ---------------------------------
 433.333   23076.94 20606.467   -   43683.397&d gger; | 3d3.(4F).4s.4p.(3P*) | z 4D* 1/2  | 3d3.4s.(5F).4d        | 4D
```
The dagger is being returned in HTML as "`†`" but it appears that the table is breaking at the wrong point (on the 'a' of 'dagger') due to the use of a FixedWidth reader in the _parse_results method of NistClass. This then throws off the parsing for every column after the third one (the 'Ei   Ek' one); the fourth column should be `3d3.(4F).4s.4p.(3P*) | z 4D* 1/2` but is instead `gger; | 3d3.(4F).4s.4p.(3P*) | z 4D*`.

This problem is particularly insidious because there's no indication to the user that anything has happened until they try to use the data and something breaks, as the parsing produces an output without any warning that something is off.

On an optimistic note, I _think_ it should be possible to fix the issue by using a regular expression to find things in the form of an HTML code (something like `&.*;`) then stripping out all matches from the raw Response text before parsing it into a Table. I'll try to see if can fix it on my own and submit a pull request.

title: Simbad.query_objectids get_query_payload returns the response rather than payload
body:
The payload in this case is super simple so it's questionable how useful to have this kwarg, nevertheless it should do what it says in the docs (and what is consistent with the other modules).

It's basically a one liner fix in `query_objectids_async` as it doesn't deal with the kwarg.

title: OAC csv parsing error

Suggested workaround: remote data_format kwarg as it shouldn't matter for the end user what server output format we parse internally.

title: NIST queries are failing with javascript in the returns
body:
This was reported to me via e-mail.

Example:
```
from astroquery.nist import Nist
import astropy.units as u
import astropy.io.ascii as aia


# Fetch Argon with vacuum wavelengths:
wl_min =  3000.0 * u.AA
wl_max = 18000.0 * u.AA
#table = Nist.query(minwav=3000 * u.AA, maxwav=18000 * u.AA,
#        linename="Ar", wavelength_type='vacuum')
table = Nist.query(300 * u.nm, 1800 * u.nm, linename='Ar',
        energy_level_unit='eV', output_order='wavelength',
        wavelength_type='vacuum')
#table = Nist.query(300 * u.nm, 1800 * u.nm, linename=str("Ar"))
#print(table)

# Exclude entries with no observed wavelength:
clean_table = table[~table['Observed'].mask]

# Drop columns I don't want:
dumb_columns = ['Lower level', 'Upper level', 'Ei           Ek', 
        'TP', 'Acc.']
clean_table.remove_columns(dumb_columns)
print(clean_table)

# ['Spectrum', 'Observed', 'Ritz', 'Rel.', 'Aki', 'fik', 'Acc.', 'Type', 'Line']

# Save table for future use:
aia.write(clean_table, 'nist_argon.dat', overwrite=True)

title: Fix for issue 1327: HEASARC errors too aggressive
body:
In Issue #1327, the HEASARC module was returning an error even though
the query was successful.  This problem occurred because the code is
searching for the word "ERROR" in the returned text, and for some
returns, "ERROR" was included in the text to mean "measurement error",
not "query error".

Keep an eye on this issue in the future, though: there may be other
classes of HEASARC query errors we're not catching now.

title: Fix 1336 adsfields: "citations" should be "citation"
body: A field name for ADS was incorrectly specified.  There are also no remote tests for ADS presently.

title: nasa_ads query returns 'None' for citations counts
body:
In astroquery v0.3.9 and v0.3.10 (pip installed), nasa_ads queries fail to return the number of citations associated with a given entry. 

Here's a MWE: 

```
from astroquery import nasa_ads as ads
query = '2018ascl.soft06027V'
result = ads.ADS.query_simple(query, cache = False)
print(result['citations'])
```
In v0.3.9 and 0.3.10, this returns:
```
citations [1]
-------------
         None
```
In v0.3.9, this returns:
```
citations [1]
-------------
3
```
Running Python 3.6.8 via a terminal shell with ipython 6.1.0 on Mac OSX 10.13.6. 
Any idea on what may be going on here ?

title: bugfixes for jplhorizons and jplsbdb
body:
This PR fixes the following bugs:

* `jplhorizons`: described in issue #1332; the new behavior will not list `H` in the resulting table if it is not defined in the raw data
* `jplsbdb`: fixes a bug in which non-existing vales for parameters will lead to a crash as the code tried to attach a unit to a `NoneType`; now, the `NoneType` is kept without trying to attach unit type

File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/site-packages/astroquery/jplhorizons/core.py", line 1061, in _parse_horizons
    H = float(HGline[1].rstrip('G'))
ValueError: could not convert string to float: n.a.                 

I would suggest adding code to return a numpy.nan in this case rather than raising the error.

title: Fix catalog parsing in `Vizier._args_to_payload`
body:
Fix for Issue #1326.

The bug was that we were using dict.get('key', 'default'), but if dict had {'key': None}, None would be used instead of 'default'.  The regression test is a simple one but required adding get_query_payload.

title: Fix airmass column issues with jplhorizons.
body:
``Horizons.ephemerides`` would crash when Horizons returned tables with no masked data.  The error occurs when attempting to fill bad values in the 'a-mass' column: ``data['a-mass'].filled(99)``.  However, with no masked data, ``ascii.read`` returns a normal ``Table``, and the 'a-mass' column is missing the ``filled`` method.

In addition, the same lines would crash if airmass was not requested in the returned table.

This PR address both issues.

```python
>>> from astroquery.jplhorizons import Horizons
>>> q = Horizons('Ceres', location='I41', epochs=[2458300.5])
>>> eph = q.ephemerides(quantities='1,8')

    return self.fn(obj, *args, **kwds)

    result = self._parse_result(response, verbose=verbose)
  File "/home/msk/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/astroquery-0.3.9.dev4979-py3.6.egg/astroquery/jplhorizons/core.py", line 1223, in _parse_result
    data = self._parse_horizons(response.text)
  File "/home/msk/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/astroquery-0.3.9.dev4979-py3.6.egg/astroquery/jplhorizons/core.py", line 1171, in _parse_horizons

AttributeError: 'Column' object has no attribute 'filled'

title: NRAO: Fix case handling in parameter validation
body:
The NRAO module was doing parameter validation incorrectly, checking for 'BnA' in a list that was forced to be all uppercase.  This adds a regression test.

Addresses issue #1282

title: Auto-logout issue with ESO retrieve_data
body:
The ESO portal automatically logs users out after 2hrs. When downloading large datasets using the EsoClass.retrieve_data function in https://github.com/astropy/astroquery/blob/master/astroquery/eso/core.py , this results in all remaining files being replaced by a html file of the ESO login page.

There are a few potential solutions to this. For example, the function could check whether the downloaded files are as expected (i.e. not a html file), or check the authentication status before downloading each file.

title: In a Vizier query, width and height are wrongly swapped
body:
I noticed this by doing simple rectangular 2MASS queries, for which the width and height are swapped in the resulting star samples. I think these are the relevant lines in the code: 

https://github.com/astropy/astroquery/blob/d950234e9fd3f17824547fed77943766aa00e3a8/astroquery/vizier/core.py#L426-L427

title: Change internal order of coordinate resolution in parse_coordinates
body:
This is to fix #1251. 

The most significant change is that degrees now explicitly assumed if the initializer cannot figure it out from the string itself (previously it was left to Sesame to decide how to parse it).

title: parse_coordinates returning incorrect results
body:
astroquery.utils.commons.parse_coordinates is appending "25" to coordinates given to it:
```
>>> from astroquery.utils.commons import parse_coordinates
>>> parse_coordinates("251.51 32.36")
<SkyCoord (ICRS): (ra, dec) in deg
    (251.5125, 32.3625)>

>>>parse_coordinates("51.0 -30.003")
<SkyCoord (ICRS): (ra, dec) in deg
    (51.025, -30.0033)>
```
This comes directly from the [Sesame service](http://cds.u-strasbg.fr/cgi-bin/Sesame) which is called on the given coordinate string via astropy's [SkyCoord.from_name](http://docs.astropy.org/en/stable/api/astropy.coordinates.SkyCoord.html#astropy.coordinates.SkyCoord.from_name).  

Looking at the documentation for SkyCoord.from_name and the Sesame service it is not clear that they are designed to take a coordinate as opposed to an object name.  Additionally, it seems unnecessary to call a resolver service simply to parse a coordinate string, so my recommendation is to avoid calling sesame at all on coordinate strings. Perhaps parse_coordinates need not also resolve objects?

title: mast query fails cryptically when too many observations are requested
body:
The following code: ``` from astroquery.mast import Observations Observations.query_criteria_async(obs_collection='HST') #FAILS ``` consistently fails with the following exception: ``` --------------------------------------------------------------------------- JSONDecodeError Traceback (most recent call last) ... ~/miniconda3/envs/astro36/lib/python3.6/json/decoder.py in raw_decode(self, s, idx) 355 obj, end = self.scan_once(s, idx) 356 except StopIteration as err: --> 357 raise JSONDecodeError("Expecting value", s, err.value) from None 358 return obj, end JSONDecodeError: Expecting value: line 1 column 1 (char 0) ``` The debugger reveals the root of the problem: the response from the query is: ``` > /Users/erik/miniconda3/envs/astro36/lib/python3.6/json/__init__.py(354)loads() 352 parse_int is None and parse_float is None and 353 parse_constant is None and object_pairs_hook is None and not kw): --> 354 return _default_decoder.decode(s) 355 if cls is None: 356 cls = JSONDecoder ipdb> p len(s) 183 ipdb> p s '\r\n504 Gateway Time-out\r\n\r\n

504 Gateway Time-out

\r\n
nginx/1.12.2
\r\n\r\n\r\n' ``` That is, there's a 504 error somewhere in the process of trying to get all the data. While it may be MAST wants to fix this, I think the real problem here as far as astroquery is concerned is that the error is a `JSONDecodeError`, which doesn't really report the true problem. So perhaps this case should be caught somehow and the true request error code passed up? cc @ceb8

title: Cannot authenticate MAST session on Linux
body:
I'm unable to authenticate with the `astroquery.mast.Observations.login()` method on GNU/Linux, but it works fine on OSX.

Printing out the cookie names in [`astroquery/mast/core.py`]( https://github.com/astropy/astroquery/blob/master/astroquery/mast/core.py ) reveals that there is none with a name containing `shibsession`.  This results in the "Authentication failed!" warning in the [`if not cookieFound:` test](https://github.com/astropy/astroquery/blob/0d2c2f1cccb02de392cce525515d344732f28170/astroquery/mast/core.py#L303).

title: SDSS query fails on very specific instances due to spaces in the SQL query
body:
Approximately one out of every 1000 queries to SDSS will give an error due to the SQL query for seemingly random differences. I've only noticed this problem in Python 2.7, but have not tested it in Python 3+.

For example this query will work
```
from astroquery.sdss import SDSS

def query(ra, dec, search_radius):
    SDSS_query = """SELECT p.objid,          -- comment
                           p.type,           -- comment
                           p.clean,          -- comment
                           p.ra,             -- comment
                           p.dec,            -- comment
                           p.psfMag_u,       -- comment
                           p.psfMag_g,       -- comment
                           p.psfMag_r,       -- comment
                           p.psfMag_i,       -- comment
                           p.psfMag_z,       -- comment
                           p.petroR50_u,     -- comment
                           p.petroR50_g,     -- comment
                           p.petroR50_r,     -- comment
                           p.petroR50_i,     -- comment
                           p.petroR50_z,     -- comment
                           p.modelMag_u,     -- comment
                           p.modelMag_g,     -- comment
                           p.modelMag_r,     -- comment
                           p.modelMag_i,     -- comment
                           p.modelMag_z,     -- comment
                           pz.z,             -- comment
                           pz.zErr           -- comment
                   FROM PhotoObj AS p , dbo.fGetNearbyObjEq(%s, %s, %s) AS n
                   LEFT JOIN Photoz AS pz ON pz.objID = n.objID
                   WHERE n.objID = p.objID
                 """
    SDSS_data = SDSS.query_sql(SDSS_query%(ra, dec, search_radius), timeout=60.0)
    print(SDSS_data)

query(251.364375, 37.0804972222, 0.5)
```

And this will fail:
```
def query(ra, dec, search_radius):
    SDSS_query = """SELECT p.objid,          -- comment
                           p.type,           -- comment
                           p.clean,          -- comment
                           p.ra,             -- comment
                           p.dec,            -- comment
                           p.psfMag_u,       -- comment
                           p.psfMag_g,       -- comment
                           p.psfMag_r,       -- comment
                           p.psfMag_i,       -- comment
                           p.psfMag_z,       -- comment
                           p.petroR50_u,     -- comment
                           p.petroR50_g,     -- comment
                           p.petroR50_r,     -- comment
                           p.petroR50_i,     -- comment
                           p.petroR50_z,     -- comment
                           p.modelMag_u,     -- comment
                           p.modelMag_g,     -- comment
                           p.modelMag_r,     -- comment
                           p.modelMag_i,     -- comment
                           p.modelMag_z,     -- comment
                           pz.z,             -- comment
                           pz.zErr           -- comment
                    FROM PhotoObj AS p , dbo.fGetNearbyObjEq(%s, %s, %s) AS n
                    LEFT JOIN Photoz AS pz ON pz.objID = n.objID
                    WHERE n.objID = p.objID
                 """
    SDSS_data = SDSS.query_sql(SDSS_query%(ra, dec, search_radius), timeout=60.0)
    print(SDSS_data)

query(251.364375, 37.0804972222, 0.5)
```

The only difference between those two queries is the number of spaces before the "FROM", "LEFT", and "WHERE" commands at the end. But there is no optimal number of spaces that will work for every query. Even though the query at the top will work for these coordinates, it will fail for others with the same error.

Changing the dec in the query from 37.0804972222 to 37.0804972223 will also fix the problem.

I've narrowed down the problem to the `response = getattr(self, async_method_name)(*args, **kwargs)` command in the `process_asyncs.py` file. All of the queries retrun a proper response = <Response [200]>, but the ones that fail return an HTML website, instead of the proper data table. Which then results in the `_parse_result` function in `SDSS/core.py` to fail because it finds the wrong number of columns in the response, since there are no columns, but only some HTML code.

My current workaround is: If the query fails, change the number of spaces at the end and try again. This happens about 0.1% of the time, which makes it hard to reproduce the problem and hard to find a common pattern among the queries that fail.

Thanks!

~/miniconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/keyring/core.py in get_password(service_name, username)

~/miniconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/keyring/backends/SecretService.py in get_password(self, service, username)

So I guess the simple solution would be to try/except the `keyring.get_password` call :

title: fix jplhorizons queries (fixes #1192)
body: JPL Horizons now requires https - queries are currently not possible. This PR changes http to https in the server url and fixes this problem (#1192).

title: Fix several bugs in atomic
body:
#1186 unearthed some issues with the atomic module:

* `wavelenght_range` is inconsistent with `lower_level_energy_range` and `upper_level_energy_range` by accepting both a Quantity object or a tuple or two Quantities. I feel we should have been more pedantic and only accept one way to do this as even though the docstring is correct it confuses users. I've lest this as is, we may need to open an issue for further discussion.
* specifying `upper/lower_level_energy_range` as a Quantity, a `TypeError` is raised. This is fixed now and test added.
* When supplying a Quantity for `wavelenght_range`, an AstropyDeprecationWarning is raised. This is fixed now by checking whether the kwarg is specified rather than its truth value.

Closes #1186

from astroquery.vo_conesearch import conesearch
