    from .async import AsyncBase
              ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax

```
As a fix I suggest to rename file astroquery/vo_conesearch/async.py and fix the imports accordingly. Would that be safe (and which files import async, do we need doc changes?)? I have to fix it in Fedora packaging soon as Python 3.7 has been imported now.

Greetings,
Christian

title: ESASky: get_maps() doesn't handle HST tar files
body:
This was originally reported by @bastianpeter at the astropy core repo, but really is an ESASky module bug:

```
from astroquery.esasky import ESASky
maps = ESASky.query_object_maps('13 29 52.7 +47 11 43')
maps_data = ESASky.get_maps(maps, missions='HST')
```

The files are actually provided as `tar`s with a content of 2 fits files and 2 jpegs, and thus `astropy.io.fits` cannot (and shouldn't) really handle that.

xref: https://github.com/astropy/astropy/issues/7569

title: Check for response errors in ESASky
body:
It would be very useful to check whether the response is a successful one or we rather get an error back. E.g. the criptic issues like #1021 is now boiled down to receiving an 500, Internal Server Error rather than response content. 

Ideally the module should exit gracefully with giving a useful error message.

body:
This is a follow-up of #1114.

I am getting this from the nightly validator:
```
WARNING: 2 not found in registry! Skipped:
        b'http://vizier.u-strasbg.fr/viz-bin/conesearch/I/243/out?'
        b'http://vizier.u-strasbg.fr/viz-bin/conesearch/II/246/out?'

For whatever reason, these two access URLs are not returned by `VOSDatabase.from_registry()` but I can query them separately via http://vao.stsci.edu/regtap/querymanager.html by using SQL statement like:
```
select * from rr.interface natural join rr.resource natural join rr.capability
    where access_url='http://vizier.u-strasbg.fr/viz-bin/conesearch/I/243/out?'
```

I might need to contact STScI VAO registry provider to get relevant server log. For now, these are just not reported as "good" in https://astropy.stsci.edu/aux/vo_databases/ . But they are still theoretically usable. 

* `http://vizier.u-strasbg.fr/viz-bin/conesearch/I/243/out?` is USNO-A1, which I think is superseded by A2, which is validated successfully.
* `http://vizier.u-strasbg.fr/viz-bin/conesearch/II/246/out?` is 2MASS, which I think has alternate access URLs that are validated successfully.

So, this is not critical.

There is also another issue with GAIA DR2 access URL: See https://github.com/astropy/astroquery/issues/1098#issuecomment-385189072

https://github.com/astropy/astroquery/blob/ac719ee24bdf5b66bd93b84100f13a7099c0d1f7/astroquery/sdss/core.py#L1009

I think using "(ra - dr / cos_dec, ra + dr / cos_dec, ..." is better. Otherwise the actual box size will shrink towards the celestial poles. Also, adding boundary detection near RA~0/360 might be helpful.

title: Allow multiple entries in NRAO queries
body: This is a bugfix for the NRAO query tool.  Previously, only single telescope configurations and single telescopes (e.g., just 'vla' or just 'gbt' or just 'all') were permitted, but the NRAO archive accepts arrays of entries.

title: Problems with some units in astroquery.gaia
body:
I ran example 1.1 from the documentation page and started looking at the results. It looks like something is screwed up with the units. My guess is that they are given in a non-standard format in the VOTable and so that the astropy units package cannot recognise them.

This is the code directly from the example:
```
import astropy.units as u
from astropy.coordinates.sky_coordinate import SkyCoord
from astropy.units import Quantity
from astroquery.gaia import Gaia
coord = SkyCoord(ra=280, dec=-60, unit=(u.degree, u.degree), frame='icrs')
width = Quantity(0.1, u.deg)
height = Quantity(0.1, u.deg)
r = Gaia.query_object_async(coordinate=coord, width=width, height=height)
```

The proper motion units work as expected. `print(r["pmra"].unit)` returns `mas / yr` and `print(r["pmra"].unit.physical_type)` correctly returns that this is an angular speed.

But `print(r["ra_error"].unit)` returns `Angle[mas]`, which is not a valid unit (it should be simply `mas`). And `print(r["ra_error"].unit.physical_type)` returns `unknown`. This problem is true for all column with units of mas.

There are similar problems for columns with units of `Angle[mas^-2]` which should be `1 / mas2`, units of `Flux[e-/s]` which should be `electron/s`, units of`Magnitude[mag]` which should be `mag`, and dimensionless quantities `Dimensionless[see description]` which can be `dimensionless_angles` or `dimensionless_unscaled` or simply `None`.

title: IRSA has changed URLs from http to https
TAP query redirect error
body:
When attempting to access a TAP service with TapPlus, some services will issue a 303 redirect that gets caught as an error. Alternative tools like Topcat follow through and deliver the data, but astroquery does not.

Example code:
```
from astroquery.utils.tap.core import TapPlus
url = 'http://www.cadc-ccda.hia-iha.nrc-cnrc.gc.ca/tap'
cadc = TapPlus(url=url)
job = cadc.launch_job("select top 100 observationID, instrument_name from caom2.Observation")
```

title: bugfix: making mast deal gracefully with no results returned
body: Because the result of dict.get(key) is false both in the case where a key is not present and where the value of the key's dictionary entry is an empty list, an erroneous exception was being through when a query returned no results.  This PR fixes that behavior.

title: Make ESO instrument query case insensitive
body:
Apparently the ``query_instrument()`` is case sensitive. It works with e.g. ``'harps'`` but gives an descriptive IndexError when one tries using ``'HARPS'``. 

We either need to give a better error, or be more user friendly and be case insensitive.

title: SIMBAD: allow carriage returns at end of line
body: Fix for Issue #931

title: Adding verify kwarg to requests to avoid SSLErrors
body:
The url of magpis has been changed to use https, while there is no certificate available with it, so we receive an ``urllib3.exceptions.SSLError: [SSL: CERTIFICATE_VERIFY_FAILED] certificate verify failed``. 

The clearest workaround is to use the ``verify=False`` kwarg in the request, so this PR adds it as a kwarg.

title: Fixes and updates to the ALMA finder chart maker
body:
(this relies on unmerged bugfixes)

The ALMA archive stopped serving up a complete list of individual footprints.
Instead, they now have an approximate amalgamated footprint box included in
each row of the HTML table, but *not* in their votables or CSVs.  I therefore
had to implement an entirely new reader and parser.

title: Sha quickfix
body:
This is a fix due to updates in the Spitzer Heritage Archive outputs, which appear to have updated.  I've update the code and the example files and this closes #884.

I've also updated the docs to use `SkyCoords` rather than `FK5`, as there seems to be a difference in how those `transform_to` works.  See https://github.com/astropy/astropy/issues/5949 for more details.

title: Query_region example in Simbad docs doesn't work
body:
http://astroquery.readthedocs.io/en/latest/simbad/simbad.html#query-a-region
```
from astroquery.simbad import Simbad
result_table = Simbad.query_region("sirius")
print(result_table)
```
Here, the problem arises because query_region only accepts co-ordinates as its first argument and fails to parse it in case of names. The error looks like this - 
```
ValueError: (u'Cannot parse first argument data "sirius" for attribute ra', ValueError(u"Syntax error parsing angle 'sirius'",))
```

SkyView.get_images and get_image_list returning empty list for valid queries

With Python 3.5.2, astropy 1.3, and astroquery 0.3.4 or 0.3.5.dev the example in the docs yields:

```python
>>> SkyView.get_image_list(position='Eta Carinae',
                  survey=['Fermi 5', 'HRI', 'DSS'])
[]
```

title: esasky incorrectly assigns SPIRE maps to filters
body:
I've just realised that for Herschel-SPIRE the maps for 250 and 500 µm are swapped somehow. Here is an example:

```python
from astroquery.esasky import ESASky as esa
maps = esa.query_object_maps('13 29 52.7 +47 11 43', 'HERSCHEL')
maps[0]['observation_id', 'instrument', 'filter', 'duration'].pprint()
# let's download only the SPIRE map for OBSID 1342237513, index 8
nmaps = len(maps[0])
maps[0].remove_rows(np.delete(range(nmaps),8))
maps[0]["observation_id","filter","duration"].pprint()
# OK, now we can download the maps
maps_data = esa.get_maps(maps)
#
hdu = maps_data['HERSCHEL'][0]['250']
hdu.info()
# ===> Maps/HERSCHEL/hspireplw1342237513_20pxmp_1461580830685.fits.gz
```

But this map with *plw* in the name is the 500 µm map and not the 250 µm one. And similarly 

```python
hdu = maps_data['HERSCHEL'][0]['500']
hdu.info()
# ===> Filename: Maps/HERSCHEL/hspirepsw1342237513_20pxmp_1461580831552.fits.gz
```
is the 250 µm map as it has *psw* in the name.

title: Fixing issues with Vizier
body:
While I was running the doctest for the vizier examples discovered a few small bugs. This PR fixes both those and the docstring.

 * examples ``Vizier.get_catalogs(catalog_list.keys())`` don't work on python3 as dict_key is not a list, rather than changing the examples, I've changed the code to always convert these to a list first
 * I think always returning computed coordinates is superfluous, if one needs them they should be asked for. Didn't find any reasons for this in issues, so removed it.
 * Dealing with the special column specifications had a bug and ``*``, returning default columns only, wasn't even  included
 * some of the doc examples just needed to be updated as more catalogues were added, etc.

Locally all the narrative docs examples for vizier passed with python3

title: Vizier always returns all the columns
body:
Vizier should treat '*' as a request for returning only the default columns (http://vizier.u-strasbg.fr/doc/asu-summary.htx), but instead it returns all of them. 

Probably #467 was a PR that changed the behaviour.

title: Simbad.list_votable_fields() filter list is not correct
body:
In Simbad.list_votable_fields() documentation, the following is stated:

```
1. The parameter filtername must correspond to an existing filter. Filters include: B,V,R,I,J,K,L.
They are checked by SIMBAD but not astroquery.simbad
```

I found out that the filter L is causing trouble, and fails to perform the query. The reason is that L is not in Simbad's filters list, as seen in Simbad's [Options and outputs](http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-fout), Fluxes/Magnitudes section. On the other hand, other filters such as H, u, g, r , i, and z, can be included.

The documentation should be changed to show the available filters and to avoid crashes due to this issue.

title: Vizier.find_catalogs str TypeError on Python 3
body:
I think `Vizier.find_catalogs` is broken on Python 3 ... e.g. for the example from the [astroquery.vizier docs page](https://astroquery.readthedocs.org/en/latest/vizier/vizier.html):

```
>>> from astroquery.vizier import Vizier
>>> Vizier.find_catalogs('Kang W51')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/deil/Library/Python/3.4/lib/python/site-packages/astroquery-0.3.dev2704-py3.4.egg/astroquery/vizier/core.py", line 174, in find_catalogs
    if 'STOP, Max. number of RESOURCE reached' in response.content:
TypeError: Type str doesn't support the buffer API
```

It works on Python 2 with a warning:

```
>>> Vizier.find_catalogs('Kang W51')
/Users/deil/Library/Python/2.7/lib/python/site-packages/astroquery-0.3.dev2704-py2.7.egg/astroquery/vizier/core.py:564: UserWarning: VOTABLE parsing raised exception: 
  warnings.warn("VOTABLE parsing raised exception: {0}".format(ex))
{u'J/ApJ/706/83': <astropy.io.votable.tree.Resource object at 0x10721cf50>, u'J/ApJS/191/232': <astropy.io.votable.tree.Resource object at 0x108917610>}
```

Looks like there's no way to make this work on Python 3?

```
>>> Vizier.find_catalogs(b'Kang W51')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/deil/Library/Python/3.4/lib/python/site-packages/astroquery-0.3.dev2704-py3.4.egg/astroquery/vizier/core.py", line 174, in find_catalogs
    if 'STOP, Max. number of RESOURCE reached' in response.content:
TypeError: Type str doesn't support the buffer API
>>> Vizier.find_catalogs(u'Kang W51')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/deil/Library/Python/3.4/lib/python/site-packages/astroquery-0.3.dev2704-py3.4.egg/astroquery/vizier/core.py", line 174, in find_catalogs
    if 'STOP, Max. number of RESOURCE reached' in response.content:
TypeError: Type str doesn't support the buffer API
```

title: astroquery.vizier not retrieving selected columns
Vizier exception unclosed token

milestone.title: v0.3
milestone.description: Version 0.3 release

body: I'm not sure if this is a bug in astroquery or something odd on my machine: ``` python from astroquery.vizier.core import Vizier import astropy.coordinates as coord import astropy.units as u column_filters = {} row_limit = 3600 radius = 44.7297340808 centerRa = 55.4474526803 centerDec = -8.88299326657 catalog = 'I/259/tyc2' v = Vizier(columns=['_RAJ2000', '_DEJ2000', '+VTmag'], column_filters=column_filters, row_limit=row_limit) result = v.query_region(coord.SkyCoord(ra=centerRa, dec=centerDec, unit=(u.deg, u.deg), frame='icrs'), radius=radius*u.deg, catalog=catalog)[0] ``` On one machine it fails: ``` site-packages/astroquery/vizier/core.py:556: UserWarning: VOTABLE parsing raised exception: warnings.warn("VOTABLE parsing raised exception: {0}".format(ex)) Traceback (most recent call last): File "", line 4, in File "site-packages/astroquery/utils/class_or_instance.py", line 24, in f = lambda *args, **kwds: self.fn(obj, *args, **kwds) File "site-packages/astroquery/utils/process_asyncs.py", line 31, in newmethod result = self._parse_result(response, verbose=verbose) File "site-packages/astroquery/vizier/core.py", line 589, in _parse_result "Exception: " + str(self.table_parse_error)) astroquery.exceptions.TableParseError: Failed to parse VIZIER result! The raw response can be found in self.response, and the error in self.table_parse_error. The attempted parsed result is in self.parsed_result. Exception: 3665:48: unclosed token ``` On another though it works. Same Python and astroquery version. When I print out `v.response.text` of the failing one I get at the end: ``` 22.215.38.6412074266.67107778-6.40412444\n56.4727900.2226917.59471.14089944-16.06510583 ``` The response length here is 687123.

The ALMA archive can result in test failures if the data are not staged fast enough:

```
>       assert totalsize.to(u.GB).value > 1

title: Unable to run sample code on Py3K; Many test failures

milestone.title: v0.2 Release Candidate
milestone.description:
Release schedule set to follow astropy 0.4:
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/wiki/Release-Calendar

body:
Running the first example code in http://astroquery.readthedocs.org/en/latest/ doesn't appear to work in my Python3 installations. It's a standard bytes-vs-strings porting issue, but it seems to affect more then just Simbad. This is with the last 0.2rc release.

The bug stems from `response` (in utils/commons.py's `send_request` method) having a `.content` attribute of bytes in Python3. This presents a problem for `SimbadResult`'s `__split_sections` method's use of regex. I started to prepare a pull request decoding `response.content` in `send_request` if needed, but I think it would involve using some of the private API of `requests.Response`.

A verbose test run (with 47 failures) is at http://astro1.panet.utoledo.edu/~jbooker/astroquery-log
For comparision, a python2 test run with four failures is at http://astro1.panet.utoledo.edu/~jbooker/astroquery-python2-log (includes other bugs)

(see https://travis-ci.org/keflavich/astroquery/jobs/28766095#L874)

title: Vizier: VOTable issues continue

milestone.title: v0.2 Release Candidate
milestone.description:
Release schedule set to follow astropy 0.4:
https://github.com/astropy/astropy/wiki/Release-Calendar

body:
Using `find_catalogs`, the tables are returned with _all_ columns included.  Many of those columns have not been VOtable-sanitized, and raise errors even with `invalid='mask'` (see #353)

```
v = Vizier(columns=['all'])
v.get_catalogs('VII/252/dr5qso') # will raise an exception
v.response.content
```

The exception is:

```
Exception: None:169:4: E06: Unknown datatype 'unsignedInt' on field 'TflagB'
```

@taldcroft I think you're in charge of votables (but if not, please fwd)?   This is a case where some component of the votable is invalid but, as far as I can tell, there are no keywords that will get astropy to read it, even incompletely.   Obviously I ought to raise this with Vizier, but is there any way astropy can skip or fix this column?

title: ESO data_retrieval fails for APEX data
body: APEX data is packaged in tarballs, not raw FITS files as apparently other instruments are.  The data retrieval code therefore needs to be modified to accept APEX data file requests, and documentation is needed.

title: Build broken
body: Something is wrong with the table parsing for the Besancon models.  It is caused by changes to astropy.tables.

title: UKIDSS catalog query fails for non-public data
body:
Hi Adam & Tom,
I'm testing UKIDSS queries with the new version of astroquery, and it seems that there's a problem for non-public data. The following example

```
    from astropy.coordinates import Galactic
    from astropy import units as u
    from astroquery.ukidss import Ukidss
    u_obj = Ukidss(username='xxx', password='xxx', community='xxx')
    cat = u_obj.query_region(Galactic(l=10.625, b=-0.38,  
                 unit=(u.deg, u.deg)),radius=6 * u.arcsec, 
                 database='UKIDSSDR8PLUS', programme_id='GPS')
```

returns the error `InvalidQueryError: Service returned with an error!` within the function `_check_page()`. I notice that the result of the query (it can be seen in `response.content`) is the same as if I were not logged in, so for some reason the query is not identifying the login. Using DR7 instead, the query works:

```
    cat = u_obj.query_region(Galactic(l=10.625, b=-0.38,  
                 unit=(u.deg, u.deg)),radius=6 * u.arcsec, 
                 database='UKIDSSDR7PLUS', programme_id='GPS')
```

By the way, maybe this is not related, but if I set the `database = 'UKIDSSDR8PLUS'`, when initializing the object `u_obj`, and then i don't use the `database` keyword in `query_region`, the database is automatically set to the default `UKIDSSDR7PLUS`, which I assume is not desired.

title: decorators prevent doctests from being collected
body: The `@class_or_instance` decorators hide the docs from pytest (and sphinx; see #204) and prevent them from being collected.  Examples can be seen in the latest commits in SIMBAD.

body:
There is _one_ votable that still won't parse.

I think the problem comes down to some interaction between monkeypatching any py3/unicode issues.  I can't make heads or tails of it.

Traceback:

```
astroquery/ukidss/tests/test_ukidss.py:140: in test_query_region

The file of interest is `votable.xml` in the `ukidss/tests/data/` directory.

If you open it in any normal context, it parses just fine:

```
import astropy.utils.data as aud
import io
from astropy.io import votable
table_link='/Users/adam/repos/astroquery/astroquery/ukidss/tests/data/votable.xml'
with aud.get_readable_fileobj(table_link) as f:
    content = f.read()
parsed_table = votable.parse(io.BytesIO(content.encode('utf-8')), pedantic=False)

with open('/Users/adam/repos/astroquery/astroquery/ukidss/tests/data/votable.xml','r') as f:
     content = f.read()
parsed_table = votable.parse(io.BytesIO(content.encode('utf-8')), pedantic=False)
```

However, within the test framework, I always get the above error.  The type is weird:

```
(Pdb) type(content)
<class 'str'>
```

vs ipython:

```
In [31]: type(content)
Out[31]: builtins.str
```

Out[28]: '::script::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::\n\nvotable {main_id,coordinates}\nvotable open\nquery coo  5:35:17.30000 -80:52:00.00000 radius=5d frame=ICRS\nvotable close\n\n::console:::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::\n\nC.D.S.  -  SIMBAD4 rel 1.207  -  2013.08.12CEST07:56:14\ntotal execution time: 29.173 secs\nsimbatch done\n\n::data::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::\n\n<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>\n<VOTABLE xmlns="http://www.ivoa.net/xml/VOTable/v1.2" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.ivoa.net/xml/VOTable/v1.2" version="1.2">\n<DEFINITIONS>\n<COOSYS ID="COOSYS" equinox="2000" epoch="J2000" system="ICRS"/>\n</DEFINITIONS>\n<RESOURCE name="Simbad query" type="results">\n<TABLE ID="SimbadScript" name="default"><DESCRIPTION>Simbad script executed on 2013.08.12CEST07:56:14</DESCRIPTION>\n\n'

I think a warning or error should appear for every query that returns invalid results?

title: Disable remote tests for all non-refactored modules

milestone.title: First Release
milestone.description:
We want releasable code!

* Requires uniform API
* Must pass tests
* Must have at least the basics fully functional (NED, Simbad, IRSA).

body: Remote tests rely on the remote server being operational and therefore render travis unreliable.   Even before refactoring the module, it's important to refactor the tests such that a remote server failure will not break the build.

title: File objects downloaded as 'closed' by default
Bug: get_query_payload should be rejected by synchronous version
body:
If you try `Service.query_region(...., get_query_payload=True)`, the `query_region_async` will return the payload, but then `query_region` will try to parse that.

Options to deal with this:
1. Add a kwarg-parsing mechanism in `async_to_sync`, e.g.:

```
if kwargs.pop('get_query_payload'):
    return result
else:
    return parse(result)
```
1. Perform some kind of caller-checking in the `_async` function 
2. Have the `_async` functions return an object that will be parsed properly into a payload

I think I prefer solution 1.

title: Frequent Build Errors for sphinx because matplotlib is slow
body: The build_sphinx travis builds frequently error, most often because of matplotlib issues.

title: SIMBAD python2.7 failures?
body:
SIMBAD seems to be unstable to changes in other modules; I suspect there may be uncaught server errors causing test failures:

This fails for python-2.7 on SIMBAD:
https://travis-ci.org/astropy/astroquery/jobs/7566041
(though I restarted it...)

This one passes:
https://travis-ci.org/astropy/astroquery/jobs/7535400

The diff between those two commits shows no changes to SIMBAD:

```

astroquery/alfa/__init__.py
astroquery/alfa/core.py

astroquery/alfa/tests/test_alfa.py

astroquery/sdss/core.py

body: Already begun in #70, but there are other python3 incompatibilities that need to be fixed; they will probably be fixed if we do #71.

title: NED docstrings cause travis failures

milestone.title: Travis Grid
milestone.description: We need to get a complete travis grid working before we can really be sure development is proceeding sanely.  Key goals are to clean up the docs and ensure py3 compatibility

body:
The NED docstrings don't work, largely because of tables that look like this:

```
---------------
|col1|col2|col3|
.....
---------------
```

We need to find a way to get those tables to play nice with numpydoc.

body:
The docstring of `ned.query_ned_basic_posn` says this:

```
Definition: ned.query_ned_basic_posn(objname='M31', root_url='http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/cgi-bin/nph-objsearch')
Docstring:
Retrieve best available position data from NED for a particular target
    Equivalent to query_ned_by_objname(objname,tid=2)

keywords:
    objname - astronomical object to search for

Returns NED_PositionDataTable with the following information:

    -----------------------------------------------------------
    |                    Name |       Unit |    Type | Format |
    -----------------------------------------------------------
    |                 pos_ref |       None |    |S19 |    19s |
    |      pos_ra_equ_B1950_d |    degrees | float64 | 25.17e |
    |     pos_dec_equ_B1950_d |    degrees | float64 | 25.17e |
    |      pos_ra_equ_B1950_s |       None |    |S14 |    14s |
    |     pos_dec_equ_B1950_s |       None |    |S14 |    14s |
    |  maj_axis_unc_equ_B1950 | arcseconds | float64 | 25.17e |
...

title: Module `coords` imported by NRAO subpackage
body: The current NRAO subpackage tries to import a `coords` module that isn't shipped here and that isn't present in the _required_ section of `setup.py` either. Where is it supposed to be ?
